section.title: Overview
section.p: Alarms are generated to alert operators of abnormal behavior. Alarms are raised by any of the NCC CNF microservices. These alarms are meant to be sent to the Element Management System (EMS) that displays them.

The alarming service is provided across a cluster of machines in a cloud environment and supports the following:
southbound interface that allows applications to generate alarms
alarm management that includes alarm processing, storage and lifecycle management
northbound interface (SNMP v2c/v3) that reports alarms to the EMS

section.title: Active alarm table and alarm logs
section.p: Active alarms are stored in Maria DB. Alarms may be viewed using Kibana, in the same way that logs are viewed.

conbody.section:
Brevity control
Sometimes on a site, alarms of a similar nature may be triggered at the same time. To a northbound management system, there will be a burst of alarms arriving which can cause overload. For example, there are multiple instances of a service running in a cluster when a network partition occurs. If half of your service instances can no longer reach the database, each service instance will send an alarm if it cannot communicate with the database. This results in hundreds of alarms being sent to the northbound management system. Brevity control will allow you to configure the NCC to send a limited number of alarms that are of a similar nature but are enough to help identify the root cause of what is happening at that time and avoid going into overload. Brevity control is introduced to control the number of similar alarms that are sent.Brevity control applies to alarms and only allows a specific number of the same alarms to pass, dropping the rest of the alarms created within the particular interval.
Brevity control is introduced at both the Application and CLOG pods inside the /etc/td-agent/td-agent.conf file. Logs related to Brevity control on alarms will be output to stdout.
The alarms are filtered on the parameter keys: alarm.key, id, and severity.
Two variables are introduced at both the CLOG and the APP node mappings in the sdc_conf file for brevity control that define how within the brevity_timeframe only a specified number (brevity_num) of the same alarms can be passed, while the rest of the alarms will be dropped, as follows:
brevity_timeframe: This allows you to configure timeframe for brevity control. The value should be greater than zero. The default value is set to 10 seconds.
brevity_num: This allows you to configure how many re-occurring alarms can be displayed or allowed within the interval of the brevity_timeframe. The value should be greater than zero. The default value is set to 2.
The Brevity control message for dropped alarms will be displayed when the second brevity control occurs on the same alarms.

section.title: Enabling alarms
section.p: To enable alarms, you configure them. For more information, see the SNMP section in the NCC CNF Installation Guide.

section.title: SNMP alarms
section.p: The NCC supports a framework for producing SNMP alarms. When an alarm is produced, the NCC maintains Active state until the alarm condition is cleared.The NCC generates an alarm timestamp in SNMP traps that can be up to five seconds after the actual event time.

section.title: Alarm trap
section.p: The alarm service provides the ability to send alarms as traps to the SNMP manager.To specify the SNMP manager, you need to configure the SNMP users parameters after instantiation. To configure the SNMP users, contact Nokia Professional Services.

section.title: Alarm identification, uniqueness, field descriptions, and parameters
section.p:
Alarm uniqueness is a composite of the following parameters:
System
SpecificProblem

In the NE3S protocol, "noiSystemDistinguishedName" + "noiSpecificProblem" can only define one alarm. So in the API, "system"/"host"/<"container">/<"service">/<"process">+"alarm.id" defines one alarm only. The "system" and "host" are mandatory. The others are the optional. ObjectName is constructed using <host>+<service>#<system>.

The following table lists alarm parameters, their corresponding representation in the OID, and the description of each parameter for systems that use the older NokiaEmsMib, where the following is the OID for the alarm index key in the ETCD database:1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.1

entry.p: The name of the object causing an alarm. The object should include the code module name (e.g. BalanceManager, RatingEngine, ServiceManager, SubscriberModel, etc.).
The Object is formatted as either:

<AlarmInstance> is only used when an <AlarmInstance> is applicable. For example, a network heartbeat alarm would set the AlarmInstance to be the name of the remote network element. All other alarms use the first format.

note.p: If "AlarmInstance" is present, a "+" is used to separate the "LocalHostName" and the "AlarmInstance‚Äù.
"LocalHostName will reflect the specific host within the NCC that reported the alarm, when applicable. A newly added system alarm may use the VNF Name in the host field.

entry.p: The defined type of an alarm as defined in the X.733 standard.
The list of key-value bindings for AlarmType is in the "Alarm types" table.

row.entry: The value of time in seconds since 00:00:00 UTC, January 1, 1970.

entry.p: The name of the problem causing an alarm as defined in the X.733 standard.
The list of key-value bindings for ProbableCause is in the "Alarm probable cause" table.

row.entry: The alarm name. The SpecificProblems field further elaborates the ProbableCause information supplied.

entry.p: The perceived severity of an alarm as defined in the X.733 standard...
The list of key-value bindings for Severity is in the "Alarm severity" table.

row.entry: Alarm Data and any additional text provided.

section.p:
The following table describes additional alarm parameters without OIDs because NCC does not send/set values for these particular parameters. Other Alarm parameters that are not set or sent by NCC
Parameter Description
RepeatCount 0
AutoClearAlarm False when alarm is automatically cleared.
OmdbKey False when alarm is automatically cleared.
OmText False when alarm is automatically cleared.
AlarmSource False when alarm is automatically cleared.
AlarmUUID False when alarm is automatically cleared.
containerFullName The full name of the container in the format: extension.container_Name
VNFCFullName The VNFC full name of the node that triggered the alarm. Only applies to cloud environments.
SystemName
Name of the system in which the event occurred.
For "system" alarms, they are about the NCC as a whole (e.g. Database failure due to too many DB nodes down). If this is a system alarm, the alarm component will use the VNF system name when reporting the alarm, as opposed to the node's host name that created the alarm.
If the alarm is about a given node, the node's host name that created the alarm is given.
Acknowledgement Acknowledgement of the status of the alarm.
AcknowledgementTime Acknowledgement of the time of the alarm.

The following table lists alarm parameters, their corresponding representation in the OID, and the description of each parameter for NE3S on systems that use the newer NOKIA-ENHANCED-SNMP-SOLUTION-SUITE-ALARM-IRP MIB module, where the following is the OID for the noiAlarmId key in the ETCD database:1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.1

row.entry: This object represents the alarm identifier of an alarm in the alarm table. It uniquely identifies an entry in the alarm table. The alarmId object is read-only even though it is used as index in the alarm table.
This object represents the System Distinguished Name (SDN) of the alarming object, which represents the faulty resource.
This object represents the event time, time of occurrence of the event in the Network Element.
This object represents the specific problem assigned to the fault situation.
This object represents the alarm text and contains basic information on the fault.
This object represents the perceived severity of the fault. Value can be set to cleared by the manager to cancel the alarm.
This object represents the additional text and provides further qualification on the fault.
This object represents the probable cause of the alarm.
This ojbect represents the event type.
This object represents the notification identifier. It is a unique value for a notification.
This object represents the acknowledgement status of the alarm. If the agent does not support the concept of acknowledgement, than the value 'indeterminate' shall be used.
This object represent the time of the last modification of the acknowledgement state of an alarm in the alarm table.
This object represent the user who made the last modification of the acknowledgement state of an alarm in the alarm table.
This object represents the alarm string identifier of an alarm in the alarm table. It uniquely identifies an alarm.
This object represents the alarm additional text 2.
This object represents the alarm additional text 3.
This object represents the alarm additional text 4.
This object represents the alarm additional text 5.
This object represents the alarm additional text 6.
This object represents the alarm additional text 7.

section.p:
The following table maps Nokia alarm type values to NE3S event types for the AlarmType parameter as defined in the supported MIB. Alarm types
Nokia alarm type Value NE3S event type Value Description
1 communicationAlarm 2 communicationAlarm This alarm type is used when an object detects a communications error.
2 qualityOfServiceAlarm 11 qualityOfServiceAlarm This alarm type is used to report a failure in the quality of service of a managed object.
3 processingErrorAlarm 5 integrityViolation This alarm type is used to report an integrity violation in a managed object.
3 processingErrorAlarm 8 operationalViolation This alarm type is used to report an operational violation in managed object.
3 processingErrorAlarm 9 physicalViolation This alarm type is used to report a physical violation in a manged object
3 processingErrorAlarm 13 securityViolation This alarm type is used to report a security violation in a managed object.
3 processingErrorAlarm 15 timeDomainViolation This alarm type is used to report a time domain violation in a managed object.
4 equipmentAlarm 4 equipmentAlarm This alarm type is used to report a failure in the equipment.
5 environmentalAlarm 3 environmentalAlarm This alarm type is used to report a problem in the environment.

The following table lists key-value bindings for the Severity parameter as defined in the supported MIB. Alarm severity
Key Value Description
3 critical Requires immediate attention.
4 major May require immediate attention.
5 minor Repairs can be delayed.
1 cleared A service affecting condition has cleared.
6 warning A general interest event occurred.
